Comment: Pt. 1
The Catholic Church, in general, has been slow to combat racism.  Some 20th Century historical events to demonstrate this are: In 1954, the US Supreme Court outlawed segregation in educational institutions. U.S. Bishops in 1958 concluded that enforced segregation could not be reconciled with the Christian view of the human person.  This weak response offered no concrete guidance or recommendations for implementation.  Other Christian denominations were much more specific---denouncing the Ku Klux Klan, and promising the integration of their church facilities.  During Vatican II---only two American bishops cited 'Race Relations' as a problematic issue in their nation. In 1962, only 9 Catholic laity journeyed from Chicago to Albany, Georgia to support a local effort against racial segregation.  This was "the largest group of American Catholics that participated in the non-violent movement."

Comment: I completely agree. Once the Church has enunciated a moral principle, that one can defend one’s self and family, the prudential judgment as to how to accomplish that is up to the faithful. Obviously the Church might have something to offer if your solution were a 5 megaton nuclear device about proportionality and so on.

The bigger problem is that every time the Church, either as a whole or at the level of an episcopal conference, weighs in on something beyond delineating moral principles and defining certain absolutes - e.g. abortion, it devalues its moral stock and becomes entangled in partisan politics.

Comment: There is another problem with this bill. Judges know the law; if they don't know the law applicable to a particular case when the case starts they will "rely on the assistance of counsel"; the lawyers will provide as long and detailed an explanation of the relevant law, complete with case citations, as any judge could possibly need.

However, at the beginning of the case the judge is supposed to start with a completely open mind as to the relevant facts; those are matters that need to be proved. "Social context" is a matter of fact, and evidence, and where relevant should be properly proved by admissible evidence. A judge should not start a case with his or her mind already made up as to those facts.

Comment: From the article: "The Liberals may even be able to deliver smaller-than-anticipated deficits"
============

There is an important distinction to note here:  The Liberals will deliver smaller than *ANNOUNCED* deficits, but probably not smaller than *ANTICIPATED* deficits.

For the past 20+ years Canadian governments have been sandbagging their budget numbers so as to "surprise" on the positive side.  The sandbagging used to be on the order of $3B to $5B/year, but Trudeau's Liberals have expanded this to close to $10B/year.

So the announced deficits are up around $30B, but the anticipated deficit is only about $20B.

... of course the real question we should be asking is why are we running a deficit when we're pretty much at the peak of a global economic cycle?  Standard Keynesian economics says we should be making BIG cuts in government spending right now to prepare for the next recession that will be coming sooner than we would like.

Today - because someone else didn't earlier try to correct a common misunderstanding or a bad usage of good words - we have many many people running around thinking that chastity is a mere joke...oh, ha, ha a chastity belt.  Let's make light and bad jokes about good things. 

So my choice - my use of free will, which is a power to do the good - is to provide counter-points to such mockery.

Comment: Toronto homes and condos and apartments have people in them, whether they're owned or rented it is irrelevant. It's all about roofs over heads.  I agree with the Green Belt initiative. The sprawl as witnessed above the city, along the 400 Hwy as an eg., is horrible on every level - land use, density, traffic, cost of servicing, and just plain ugly.  The very best neighbourhoods in Toronto and around the world have a mix of density and use - Leaside, Forest Hill, The Kingsway to name 3.  The objective of planning, zoning and taxes should be to vastly increase supply of mid-to higher rise housing along all major routes in Toronto, well beyond the current activity.  There's virtually nothing but retail and one floor walk-ups along Bloor from the St. George subway to Islington.  The City is constantly harping about cycling in European cities, like that's going to work in the refrigerator Toronto is for months on end, but it's density and the beauty of the streetscapes they need to push.

Comment: While this opinion piece is written by parties who have a vested interest and must be carefully scrutinized, they make some good points.  Lower paid non-tenured faculty are an important part of an efficiently run modern University.  It is important to have a portion of the faculty that takes teaching as a first priority rather than research.  The teaching portion of the faculty is cost effective in supporting the primary educational function of the University.  Research is a secondary function of the University and it is very expensive.  Tenure-track faculty are typically heavily involved in research which requires substantial time.  Such faculty may teach only one course per term (or none).  The trustees, as representatives? of the citizens of Oregon, must decide whether to go with cost effective contract employees or expensive tenure-track faculty.  Truth be told, research provides limited benefit to Oregonians but is very expensive.  (A former tenured professor.)

Comment: As Nature magazine explained in 2012, “climate attribution” — the attempt to link singular weather events to manmade global warming — “rests on a comparison of the probability of an observed weather event in the real world with that of the ‘same’ event in a hypothetical world without global warming.” As critics have observed, such attribution claims “are unjustifiably speculative, basically unverifiable and better not made at all.”

The editors of the journal concluded: “Better models are needed before exceptional events can be reliably linked to global warming.”

Comment: I don't think the article is correct.  Could you please provide the statute.

AS 11.81.350e1 covers car jacking, which this is not.
AS 11.81.350e2  requires that "another person, other than the perceived offender, is inside of the vehicle".  Even though there was a passenger, I wouldn't think an accomplice count as "another person".

AS 11.81.350(e) a person (2) outside of a vehicle may use deadly force upon another when and to the extent the person reasonably believes it is necessary to terminate what the person reasonably believes to be the theft of that vehicle when another person, other than the perceived offender, is inside of the vehicle; this paragraph does not apply to a person outside of a vehicle who is involved in a dispute with a person inside of the vehicle who is a household member of that person; in this paragraph, "household member" has the meaning given in AS 18.66.990 .

Comment: From what I can see on Twitter, the ‘handler’ account for this round of fake Twitter is @XabisoVili. The approach of this account to get to this point is quite interesting. The account was created on 30 April and featured only two tweets in May. During this time, an aggressive following policy was adopted, in the hope to get people to follow back and gain traction and critical mass, while taking time to conform to Twitter’s following policy. Everyone and everything was followed, including escort services in various countries, and accounts tweeting exclusively in foreign scripts such as Arabic and Chinese.

Comment: Part 1
Sorry, but Church history shows that you are incorrect here.  People didn't just believe that folks came to believe that Jesus was divine as quickly as you may have assumed.  

The First Ecumenical Council of Nicaea [325] tackled issues that were more difficult than you are highlighting.  The question that the great theologian Arias was posing was that ONLY the Father was un-begotten, and that Jesus was created.  Arius DID BELIEVE that Jesus as SON possessed a dignity superior to everyone else.  Arius was very persuasive among the Greek bishops.  Since the unity of Christianity was at stake here, the Emperor Constantine was hoping for someone to come forward with a solution to the problem.  A solution came from a bright young deacon attending the council, whose name was Athanasius.  Athanasius believed that an article of faith was needed and then he presented three concepts that the Council Fathers could accept 1) The Son was 'homoiousious' 'of like substance with the Father.

Comment: Missing from this story was any mention of John Dellenback's accomplishments representing Oregon's 4th Congressional District from 1964-72. He was a principled, independent thinker among Oregon's moderate Republicans (remember them?) A devout Presbyterian who favored bow ties, Dellenback was admired by constituents of all political persuasions and steadfastly refused to accept any campaign contributions. He was among the many Republicans swept out of office in the wake of the Watergate scandal, losing his seat to Jim Weaver, a liberal Democrat from Eugene. Dellenback later directed the Peace Corps in the Ford administration. In Congress, he crafted legislation establishing the Oregon Dunes National Recreation Area and holding contractors accountable for oil spills from the Alaska pipeline. Eugene is fortunate to have Dellenback's daughter Barbara in our community continuing her father's philanthropic activities.

Comment: On the subject of home growing, there seems to be a couple of points of confusion. First, home-grown does not necessarily mean grown indoors. I don't grow potatoes in my house, and I wouldn't grow marijuana in my house. For those who do want to grow indoors, it's a house plant that carries no more inherent risk than any other house plant. If you grow a lot of any plant indoors, especially if you're trying to create conditions to maximise your crop, you can get mould issues and such, but this applies to African violets just as much as it does to cannabis. Four plants won't be a problem.

The whole impaired driving thing is a red herring. First, there's no proof that stoned driving needs to be prevented; the evidence tends to support the conclusion that being stoned simply does not make you a more dangerous driver. Second, there are lots of people driving under the influence of marijuana now; there's no reason to think legalization will mean significantly more of them.

Comment: FYI - The Ko'olauloa Health Center is Federally Qualified Community Health Center.  It is one of 15 FQCHCs operating in Hawaii, mostly in rural or neighbor island communities. Comment: There have been articles in ADN over the years on this; studs are a minority cause.  The principle reason for rutted roads stems from the aggregate (rock) size spec'd by DOT in the current asphalt mix.  In the 60's, 70's, etc a larger size was used and stood up to all traffic better.  It's more expensive so DOT now spec's a cheaper, smaller size that wears faster.  You never saw ruts like these in the 60's and 70's and studded tires were the norm then, not the exception.  Lane traffic density was the same; the Glen was a two lane highway then, everything drove them.  Late 70's, early 80's saw the first "All Season" tires show up, most were junk but BF Goodrich or GoodYear had one that was better than others, the Arriva or such was the type.

Comment: True story.  I can't tell you what we were doing because the operation was so compartmentalized few if any new the whole story.  But, my portion of it was to help set-up an ice camp above the arctic circle for the "scientists" to arrive and set-up some equipment and make it operational.  It is a struggle to relieve one's self in those kinds of conditions.  When the "scientists" arrived with their equipment, some of it was in wooden crates about seven feet long and a foot wide.  We erected these boxes in the snow and ice (envision side by side fence posts) to form a wind break and privacy wall.  We dubbed this edifice "Dump Towers".  This was back in the mid 1990's long before our president elect was even considering political office, so no offense intended.  We just thought it was a neat play on pop or should I say current culture at the time.

Merry Christmas! and Happy Holidays! everyone.

P. S.  We didn't see Santa's work shop up there.

Comment: This is a shocking argument from a criminal lawyer.

3 out of 1000 sexual assaults result in a conviction? If these other 997 sexual assaults are indeed real, and provable, and meet the legal definition instead of the often far looser definition created by sociologists for inflating numbers, why aren't there more convictions? 

Nobody is prepared to suggest Crown offices are presented with mountains of solid sex assault cases and refuse to prosecute because they're sexist meanie-heads. Indeed the opposite is true - Crown prosecutes as often as possible and very often with terrible evidence, simply because of public pressure. 

Finally, given that each case is judged on its individual evidence and merit, how can *any* conviction percentage be considered "too high", "too low", or "the right amount"? Too low or high compared to what standard? This argument has a totally nonsensical foundation.

Comment: Ever electoral system in every modern democracy has its quirks. The electoral college and easy gerrymandering just happen to be the American quirks.

I just so happen to live in one (Canada) of those "any other country in the world" where you figure Hilary would have won because of the popular vote. Our quirks are different--under the right circumstances, a party with 40% of the popular vote can win a majority of the seats in parliament--but the effect is the same. Democratic elections operate under a sets of rules, and the fair and square winner of elections are those who win by those rule. 

The essence of a stable democracy is that the winners under the rules that prevail at the time of an election are accepted by the populace as legitimate. The notion that Trump's win, no matter how distasteful, is an any way illegitimate is inherently anti-democratic and thus dangerous.

Comment: My concern was not for those handling the litter, which is obviously a skill best acquired in the vertical environment, but for the live person used to fill the basket. Why not use a simulated victim instead of a live person to simulate a victim? Why don't you have a shield to protect their face at least? Did Hamlin discard my blue coveralls with SAR patches that I donated for ease of victim simulation, or do you need another set? We can't eliminate risk entirely, only reduce it. As a volunteer firefighter I went through Burn-to-Learn exercises at the state fire academy, and had a limited amount of swift-water rescue training, but would you think it appropriate to put a live person into a burning building to simulate a victim you needed to extricate, or ask them them to swim into rapids and strand themselves to simulate a victim? We just used a bundle of ropes to simulate a victim. I would suggest that you consider the same alternative, to minimize the risk you take with others lives.

Comment: Or maybe nature is doing what is has done for billions of years (on Earth).  And maybe our human perception is wacky.  How?

1.  There are more people on every part of the planet, covering more area and with more people in most locations.  So any natural event affects somebody, and sometimes lots of people.

2.  Most of these people are better connected than ever before, and share their news.

3.  News, whether informal sharing or big media, further distorts our perception.  If not outright exaggeration, then the bias inherent in reporting disastrous events makes us edgy.  How many news headlines and Facebook posts say things like "nothing happened today"?

4.  Human memory and history is way too short to appreciate natural cycles and earth history.

5.  Human nature tends towards catastrophism, from biblical end times to science fiction apocalyptic fantasies.  And humans, collectively and individually, see themselves as the center of the universe, so anything that happens is SERIOUS.

Comment: 2-" What is the relationship between the tribes and the individual states?

Because the Constitution vested the Legislative Branch with plenary power over Indian Affairs, states have no authority over tribal governments unless expressly authorized by Congress. While federally recognized tribes generally are not subordinate to states, they can have a government-to-government relationship with these other sovereigns, as well. 

Furthermore, federally recognized tribes possess both the right and the authority to regulate activities on their lands independently from state government control.  They can enact and enforce stricter or more lenient laws and regulations than those of the surrounding or neighboring state(s) wherein they are located. Yet, tribes frequently collaborate and cooperate with states through compacts or other agreements on matters of mutual concern such as environmental protection and law enforcement. "
https://www.bia.gov/frequently-asked-questions

Comment: I would like to throw in a question.   First of all, I was a special education teacher at Mt. Iliamna back in the 1990s when it was preschool special education with a few regular-ed preschoolers invited in, as peer models.   Yes, parents had a difficult time getting on the base and participating in their children's education.   Here is my question:   Since a majority of the (current) ASD schools are grouped in the area near the Government Hill Gate, why can't the land be deeded over to the Municipality?   Clearly, that is what happened with Government Hill School.    The official fence and "gate" can be moved beyond the ASD buildings, and access would be easier for civilians and school personnel.   Military parents would have no problem going in and out.  The federal government has already combined and downsized JBER and might be amenable.   Students can always be transitioned into their neighborhood schools on a trial basis, & still have a school to which they can return, if needed.

Comment: i'm all for co-management, but i have to imagine that there first has to be a consensus among all folks living along the river, from the mouth on up.  despite the presence of local grassroots organizations, there's  a considerable amount of inter-river conflict.  if it can't be remedied, co-management would be difficult to maintain, if at all implement.  there are too many people and not enough fish.  sacrifices need to be made by all folks up and down the river, but especially so in the more densely populated lower river villages; those that get the first pickings.  on the whole, there are more resources, both subsistence and otherwise, in the lower river, than the middle and upper portions.  the moose moratorium seemed to work.  i think we can see the same results with kings, as long as people are willing to make sacrifices.  king salmon aren't the only species of fish swimming up and down that river, and folks out there are no strangers to adaptation.

Comment: In metro Vancouver entire housing projects are sold overseas.   Should working families in Canada,  refugees and new immigrants,  compete with overseas wealth for homes?

In China 60 million housing units are sold and empty to satisfy demand for housing as a commodity.  Demand for housing as a safety deposit box here has resulted in 80,000 sold and empty homes. 

Before the implementation of the 15% FB tax, some areas of metro Vancouver like Richmond, Burnaby, and West Van saw 25-30% of sales go to offshore buyers.  The tax has abated this somewhat, but so has the diversion to proxy buyers and loopholes.

All 3 levels of government set policy and procedure pertaining to  housing.  Many countries regulate who can or cannot buy homes,  restrict sales to the domestic market, or tax accordingly.

No one is entitled to affordable rents in downtown Toronto or Vancouver.  But we are entitled to a government that places the best interests of working families over non resident speculation.

Comment: Unless and until we commodify our water, we will treat it as if it has no value.  The world is a thirsty place and Canada has the water the world needs.  By bottle, by tanker or by pipeline we should be selling our water to those who will pay for it.

We have a natural resource the Saudis can only be envious of.  When their oil is burned, it's bad for the environment.  When it is gone, it's gone.  When a better, cheaper or more environmentally benign energy source becomes available, their resource becomes worthless.

Our water is 100% renewable, plentiful, can be harvested with little to no environmental impact and if husbanded carefully is a resource that will enrich Canada for generations.  And it can never be replaced by an alternative product.  Once consumed by the end-user to whom we export it, the only thing they will need is more.

As Canadians, we are absolutely foolish if we don't capitalise on the bounty that our water will provide for Canada and for its consumers worldwide.

A properly administered plan is neither unsustainable nor expensive.

Comment: For those investors at the reaping rather than sowing/growing stage I believe that FN and MKP are worthy of consideration.

FN is Canada's largest non-bank originator and underwriter of mortgages and has a current yield of 6.9%

MKP's current yield is 8.1%. Dividends have increased steadily from $0.76/annum in 2005 to the current $1.28/annum. It should be noted that MKP is a MIC (mortgage investment corporation) and as such the dividends are classified as interest income for tax purposes - accordingly it may best be held in a registered account. It is also worth noting that MKP is the only publicly traded MIC that is regulated by the OSFI.

I have owned both for years.

Comment: Jesse, I agree with you regarding the bus fare. IF we truly want to accomplish two worthy goals, 1) make it easier for people to travel, whether to work, shop or for recreation AND 2) reduce auto traffic, carbon consumption, parking, etc., we should reduce rather than raise the bus fare.

IMO, toll roads create inconveniences and administrative costs. I think raising the price of driving is most easily handled by increasing a fuel tax, both to create a disincentive for driving and to raise revenue to subsidize the integrated mass transit system. An increased gas tax allows people to save money IF they hop on the Bus.

It is often objected that a gas tax is regressive, shifting the tax burden to people who live far away, are forced to commute long distances and often drive older, less fuel-efficient cars. The regressivity of a gas tax can be offset by lowering taxes on low income residents and/or providing a tax credit for low income people.

Comment: Hi, I'm a water/leakage management technology consultant from the UK. It is common all over the western world to reduce water network pressure and not to increase it. Higher network water pressure increases the flow rate of underground leaks; increases the water customers draw for their own needs (car washing/gardening); induce bursts which cause interruptions to customers' water supply and decrease pipe lifetime. The state of Washington may not have water scarcity issues but I don't see the sense in losing more water and damaging water infrastructure whilst poisoning nature with chlorinated water, all to give customers a luxuriously high water pressure. The more water that is lost from water networks, the more that needs to be drawn from nature. I don't see anything in this article that tells me why water pressures are being increased across the network to then only be decreased (at a massive cost) at the customer boundary.
I'd be really interested to know the backstory to this scheme

Comment: The FBI's annual report on crime statistics, which is similar to our UCR because they get info from police forces clear across the US and collate it, indicated that the rate of provably fraudulent claims for violent crimes averaged 2%, excluding sexual assault.  Why was sexual assault excluded?  Because the rate for that one crime alone was FOUR TIMES HIGHER, at 8%. In both cases, this was the FLOOR of the behaviour, because only cases that were provably fraudulent were counted. Cases that were likely fraudulent, but couldn't be proven so, were listed as indeterminate.

Now, opinions on actual false rates are as variable as the weather, but suffice it to say, the fact there's a leap of ANY kind between those two statistics should be enough evidence to give pause to the 'just believe' crowd. The proper stance for any investigator is neutral.

Comment: You are technically incorrect. Dark windows absorb or reflect solar radiation rather than allowing direct entry into the vehicle. Comment: We may not be guilty for the crimes perpetuated on indigenous peoples (by crimes we mean here "cultural genocide" as documented by the TRC final report) but we are responsible. Today, in 2017, in virtually all measurable aspects of life (health, education, sanitary conditions, water quality) indigenous people suffer worse outcomes than whites. That's a fact. Comment: Good on New Brunswick for trying to address electoral reform. I would welcome lowering the voting age - there's no evidence that younger voters are any more childish than the current electorate.
Preferential ballots also make sense, though I would prefer a second round run-off election between the two candidates who polled the best in the first round. That allows you to vote with your heart in the first round and with your head in the second.
One system that makes increasingly less sense in a polarizing world is proportional representation. The NDP has cited the success of that system, pointing to places and times where there was societal consensus, like Western Europe after WWII. Unfortunately, there are a host of examples of how poorly PR works in divided societies: Israel struggles to form coalitions and ends up beholden to the radical policies of tiny parties; the Netherlands struggles to maintain its half millennium tradition of tolerance, and then there was Weimar.

Comment: Linking Charlie Gard's case to the NHS is inappropriate, I think. What's really at issue is UK law (and EU human rights laws), which states that the child's interests come first, and does not apparently in practice privilege the parents' interpretation of what that might be. Charlie's doctors have argued that experimental treatment is highly likely to be ineffective, and that since he is probably in considerable pain, it would not be in his best interests to undergo more medical treatment. Personally, I don't know what I think about the latest EU court decision, but the US and Canada have struggled with similar issues re. who has the expertise and authority to turn off life support (doctors versus family; family member versus family member). Point being: this isn't about single payer.

Comment: The states could also continue to band together to effect the National Popular Vote as the law of the land and effectively eliminate the EC:
The National Popular Vote Interstate Compact (NPVIC) is an agreement among a group of U.S. states and the District of Columbia to award all their respective electoral votes to whichever presidential candidate wins the overall popular vote in the 50 states and the District of Columbia. The compact is designed to ensure that the candidate who wins the most popular votes is elected president, and it will come into effect only when it will guarantee that outcome.[2][3] As of June 2017, it has been adopted by ten states and the District of Columbia. Together, they have 165 electoral votes, which is 30.7% of the total Electoral College and 61.1% of the votes needed to give the compact legal force.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Popular_Vote_Interstate_Compact

Comment: The advice on priorities is backwards, IMHO. With pension splitting available (because a DB pension is available, in addition to CPP and OAS) their focus should be on maximizing TFSAs first, then RRSPs. Unless either of them are in the top marginal rate now, focusing on their RRSPs may add to their post-retirement tax burden and the potential for clawbacks (the limits of which I believe could be lowered in the future). Also, the flexibility of TFSAs (withdraw at any time tax free and re-contribute the following year, etc.) far surpasses that of RRSPs.

Comment: I have analyzed the location of basement flooding reports across Toronto for the May 2000, August 2005 and July 2013 based on proximity to overland flow paths and river floodplains and have categorized each flood report based on the date of construction (design standards) of the street. The full details are here:
https://www.slideshare.net/RobertMuir3/urban-flood-risk-from-flood-plains-to-floor-drains
In brief what this GIS analysis reveals is that i) little flooding is in river floodplains (only a few percentage of flood reports are in TRCA regulated areas), ii) overland flow, or lost rivers, and creeks contribute to higher flood density - that is, uncontrolled flow from streets that gets into homes, and iii) areas built before the 1980's with weeping tiles (i.e., foundation drains) tied into the sanitary sewer have the highest density of flooding - it is the extraneous wet weather flow from the illicit roof connection and foundation drains that overwhelm sanitary sewers.

Comment: It really is far past time for an Anchorage sales tax to provide  some  offsetting balance and relief for property owners -  Not o raise additional revenue -
just to offset the always increasing burden on lower/mid-income homeowners, and the increasing percentage of retired homeowners whose real income always fall behind with the increasing costs associated with aging; & with our growing inflation. 
A minimally regressive sales tax on goods (With exemptions for grocery foods, prescriptions & medal, utilities etc) AND  on services (legal, accounting, haircuts, fast foods,etc)  need not be a revenue increase – but  be a substitute for a % of owner-occupied property taxes, & can be capped at a mid-range property assessment level.
As a substitute for some property taxes, it it would raise alternate revenues from tourists and Statewide Anchorage shoppers and relieve tax-stressed
low-to-mid income home-owners.
The tax can be capped at $50 for major purchases (cars, appliances). 
Worth a try?

Comment: Tiny homes are affordable, ecological and sustainable. Just like any other housing stock, it depends on how it is built and with what materials. Tiny houses are models for renewable and green technologies, and allow for gentle density close to amenities and in established neighbourhoods. Vancouver needs a variety of housing, high and low density and everything in between. It also needs affordable homeownership, based on a variety of sizes, tenure and built forms. Tiny houses can be passive. Just like apartments. You're right. But apartments can't be purchased for $20,000-100,000 in Metro Vancouver. Tiny houses can also act as spaces that change over time: from backyard rentals and downsizing units to art workshops or nanny/nurse quarters. It's about advocating for diverse forms of housing, to meet the needs of diverse populations. Single family, townhouses, condos and apartments...we need to innovate the way we build. This is one way.

Comment: There is a lot to not like in the tax plan. The most mean-spirited to me is removing the deduction for teachers buying classroom supplies. I'm no accountant, but the existing deduction merely lessens the sting of teachers using personal funds to make sure their kids can get an education. It should be a tax credit! 

Also bizarre is the clarifying language on pass-through corporations (bias alert, I have a pass-through entity which provides most of my income). It would reduce the tax rate to 25%, but only for corporations where the person is not actively working (or at least, for 70% of their income arbitrarily enough). So it seems to be designed to not reward a small store on Main Street, where Mom and Pop and a few employees run the place, but only reward "tax dodge" structures where money collects at a pass-through entity from income earned elsewhere.

Comment: My grand parents all lived to between 79 and 86 years of age, the last died in 2004. They were from a very different generation as are my parents and myself.

There are marked differences in each of the three generations. My grand parents generation typically lived full active lives right up until their deaths at home. Far fewer of my parents generation die at home from natural causes. Many end up in extended care facilities with multiple health problems. My generation (boomers) are going to see an even larger number in extended care facilities and at an earlier age, its already happening.

Life expectancy is declining in Canada and most western countries.

My grand parents life expectancy was 59 male, 61 female, yet they lived 20 plus years longer. My parents 63 male, 66 female, living less than 20 years longer. My generation 67 male, 73 female and we live closer to 10 years past expectancy.

Comment: Danielle, I agree UBI is morally justified, and likely to become increasingly necessary (IMO) in a wider range of plausible 21st century future scenarios. Current types of UBI are listed in my comments elsewhere in this thread prefacing an Evonomics.com article entitled "The Conversation about Basic Income is a Mess." 

These include ideas "invented" to address the historical mal-distribution--and often outright theft--of landed property "rights",  e.g. the late 18th century thinking of Thomas Paine (in Agrarian Justice), the late 19th century thinking of Henry George (in Progress and Poverty), and the mid- to late-20th century thinking of Louis Kelso (in The Capitalist Manifesto and Democracy & Econ Power), as well as the Gilman and Robertson versions of a "Common Heritage Dividend."

Comment: I take it you're not a native English reader, because what I said bears no resemblance to your comment.

I was replying to this false statement by Susan.Hoyt3: 

"Resistance is not permissible when the occupation is the result of the aggression by those now occupied."

As a general statement about the laws of war, humanitarian .law, and international law, that's 100% false. Citizens of an occupied land may always lawfully take up arms to repel an invader. This was true before the United Nations was created, and it's even more so since. Under UN Treaty the onus is always on the occupying force to withdraw from lands outside its borders, unless it is duly authorized to remain there by order of the UN Security Council. And even if it is authorized to be there that in no way denies citizens the right to resist through armed force, as long as they do so in accordance with the laws of war.

Far from being authorized to occupy Palestine, the UN has repeatedly ordered Israel to withdraw.

Comment: I had to look it up: The disqualification of a judge for a particular lawsuit or proceeding, especially due to some possible conflict of interest or prejudice.
In the United States, the term "recusal" is used most often with respect to court proceedings. Two sections of Title 28 of the United States Code (the Judicial Code) provide standards for judicial disqualification or recusal. Section 455, captioned "Disqualification of justice, judge, or magistrate judge," provides that a federal judge "shall disqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned."

Comment: Veritatis Splendor is essentially Saint John Paul's redux of the Syllabii on Error by Blessed Pius IX and Saint Pius X.  It is a rear guard action in defense of the fantastic Natural Order and a doctrine of original sin that presupposes the reality of the Eden myth.  It is essentially anti-pastoral.  It would refreshing if Pope Francis preached a more realistic view of morality - one that existed in the lives of the people involved rather than one based on the old superstitions of doctrine past.  Sins happen to people, not to God or some natural order idealized by the Vatican.  Amoris Laetitia is an attempt to break us out of that cycle.  While many of us would welcome a repudiation of faith as superstition, many of the weak of faith, including the four ex-pastors, would not be able to handle it.  Faith is not loyalty to the Church, it is trust in God and His benevolence to people in pain.

Comment: From looking at the maps, the buffer to any of the Wallace Falls park trails is quite generous. I have zero recreational concerns about this sale. Stop wasting effort here and look for matters of actual concern.

"They want to void the sale, force the state to perform a full environmental impact statement *and recoup any legal expenses.*"

By which they mean: bill above actual rates for Equal Access to Justice Act reimbursements.

When a law was proposed to limit legal reimbursements for EAJA claims to no more than $200 per hour, it was environmental groups who sunk the bill, because it hurt their business model of paying recent grads and a paralegals normal wages to produce mountains of paperwork more than the state lawyers have the time to disprove, win a suit based not on its merits but on uncontested claims, and file for reimbursements at the rates they claim as their standard, not necessarily what they actually paid, with the difference funding perks for their principals.

Comment: The recent US bombings in Afghanistan and Syria may have been done using unconventional bombs (MOAB and cruise missiles), but really they were just conventional propaganda bombs.

Bombing a Syrian military airfield (at a cost of about US$60 million in cruise missiles) was so ineffective that Syrian bombers were using it within hours. But as a boost to Donald Trump's popularity, it was a smash hit.

The bombing of an Afghan tribal region probably did far less damage than claimed (warning the locals likely also warned the insurgents). But in terms of its real purpose--to overshadow bad news about the US killing 18 Kurdish allies in Syria and nine civilians in Afghanistan a few days earlier, and to boost Donald Trump's popularity--it hit the target.

Trump has discovered spectacular bombing attacks as an effective means of feeding his hunger for popularity while distracting attention from bad news. We can therefore expect more of them.

Comment: I disagree somewhat with Kate Taylor's conclusion. Increasing the tax subsidy for CBC to replace relinquished ad revenue seems a bit like 'rewarding' a misbehaving child. CBC shouldn't have been in the ad business while being subsidized in the first place. To use that ad revenue to build an even bigger empire, then seek reward to preserve that empire seems more than a little disingenuous. I support 'appropriate' government funding for CBC; but not until there is a thorough review and determination of precisely what the CBC empire should consist of, how many enterprises it should entail and to serve what purpose? Until someone can rationalize that, no one knows how much money CBC actually needs or deserves to appropriately fulfill its mandate as a 'public' ad-free broadcaster. Given CBC's seeming inability or refusal to live within its means, I am not ready, and I don't believe many Canadians are, to simply accept CBC's suggestions or demands for what that real number should be.

Comment: "On a $5,000 net in-kind withdrawal, you'd pay $1,250 – 20 per cent – as mandatory withholding tax from cash held within the RRSP, explains Aaron Hector, vice-president of Calgary-based Doherty and Bryant Financial Strategists. On your tax return the following year, you'd pay tax on $6,250 of gross RRSP income at your top marginal rate: If you're at the 46-per-cent tax rate, that is $2,875 of tax, of which you have paid $1,250 and $1,625 remains owing, for a total of $5,750. (But the adjusted cost base for the withdrawal-in-kind remains $5,000.)"

Comment: ""how do you know, rail is not operating yet. do you have powers to see in the future""

Not  a single rail projection has been correct so far, except projections from rail critics.

Not a single rail project in the US met ridership projections.  Some states weren't even close.

Would you like to personally wager $5000 that rail will not meet their projections?   I can establish an escrow fund to hold the money until rail is up and running.

12 cars at maximum capacity of 800 every 5 minutes for an hour is 9600.  Say rail goes at maximum capacity (highly unlikely) for 3 hours in the morning and the same in the afternoon.

9600 x 3 = 28800.   Morning and afternoon = x 2 = 57600.

Where will the remaining 63,400 daily weekday riders come from?  And  that's with rail running at max capacity for 3 hours straight, which is highly unlikely.

Comment: See the decision in Bartnicki v. Vopper in which the Supreme Court held, in a 6-3 opinion delivered by Justice John Paul Stevens, that the First Amendment protects the disclosure of illegally intercepted communications by parties who did not participate in the illegal interception. "In this case, privacy concerns give way when balanced against the interest in publishing matters of public importance," wrote Justice Stevens. "[A] stranger's illegal conduct does not suffice to remove the First Amendment shield from speech about a matter of public concern."

Comment: A survey of Colorado voters in 2008 showed 68% overall support for a national popular vote for President.

Support for a national popular vote for President has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed. In the 41 red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range - in rural states, in small states, in Southern and border states, in big states, and in other states polled. 

With the National Popular Vote bill, all of the presidential electors from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes in all 50 states (and DC)—thereby guaranteeing that candidate with an Electoral College majority.

Comment: I'm not a fan of Trump and I think his lack of policy in many areas is becoming a slow-moving disaster. But, in this case I do wonder if introducing a dose of unpredictability (in a measured way) might actually work. It means the risk to NK in becoming too aggressive becomes harder for them to gauge. And, it gives China an opportunity to play 'nice cop' to Trump's 'crazy cop' -- and an opportunity to appear 'statesman-like' on the world stage, which might be attractive to China. The rhetoric might continue to heat up, but what will be telling is what NK actually does in terms of tests and missiles. 

When it comes to NK, nothing else has worked so far and there are no good military or regime-change options. Trump seems to have a wonderful grasp of creating and sustaining drama -- maybe that's exactly what's needed here. He needs a win and this would be a big one -- keeping the lid on NK. Given the crazy political world we live in, that's about as close to hopeful as I get these days.

Comment: As a nurse in 1972 when I graduated from nursing school we had preventive health care as the focus of all patient care, the first line of defense by using health education and reliable treatment of chronic diseases to prevent hospitalizations.   We had the medical delivery system in place to achieve this goal. The hospital system in the big city I lived in had "satellite" clinics all over in community neighborhoods, I worked as a student in several of them. My point is that I am for "managed" care which is the new term for this older method of delivering health care to people,  so I support this because it saves not only money but peoples health and lives, and if you don't have your health...... however I have a deep concern about Alaska having worked the medical care delivery system in place and been a patient of for years, do the communities have in place the resources they need to deliver this type of care or will it all be in the larger cities which is a burden to some residents?

Comment: The unemployment rate does not measure how many people should fall into the unemployed category and exaggerates employment and how much of the potentially working population is employed. However, the labor force participation exaggerates the number of people who are out of the labor force because it picks up people who are retiring for example. The best rate to make up for these factors is the US U-6 rate-- often called the "Real Unemployment Rate" which adds to "unemployed" the people who have a sought a job but cannot get a job "discouraged workers", plus it picks up part time workers who have to work for economic reasons (they are counted as unemployed because they cannot find full time employment). Using this measure, unemployment in Colorado rises from 2.3% to 69%, and Hawaii unemployment rises from 2.7% to 7.1%. Hawaii falls from 3d to 10th in rate of employment.

Um, what?

"the United States, whose rampant cultural production..."

What?!?

For crying out loud, American movies and music are popular, meaning that regular folks in Toronto and Manchester and Mumbai and Hong Kong like to consume them. Comment: The PFD is not personal property. This is a common misconception. It is revenue for all the citizens of the State to share just like oil taxes, fuel taxes, corporate income taxes, etc.

Out of that common pot, we pay for our obligations. In the past we could afford to pay a Dividend too but that is no longer the case.

However, with new technologies, the automobile is going to become a cleaner, safer, and more convenient efficient mode of transportation than ever before.  Autonomous vehicles will enable us to put more traffic on our existing infrastructure (should mean less rubber-necking, less  congestion).  When coupled with ride sharing services, car-pooling will be even cheaper and more convenient, and for those who don't carpool, they represent a way to remain productive even through gridlock - get picked up from home, comfortably eat your breakfast, brush your teeth, and start work during your commute.  If anything, we should be considering how to accommodate more cars coming into the city - perhaps autonomous-only roadways?  These vehicles are coming, and we'd better start thinking about how they will affect our cities.

Also: Less revenue from traffic/parking tickets

Comment: Not really - they're so light that they just "bounce" out of the way (the added mass of a larger vehicle actually makes it harder to keep the cabin intact in a high speed crash). They have crumple zones comparable to any other compact vehicle for momentum absorption- even in a midsize the driver's feet are roughly just behind the front wheels, with the front end overhang mostly cosmetic. Further, the lower power and centre of mass makes it less likely you'll get into a crash in the first place. 

The sorts of crash where occupant survival is questionable ... are pretty hit and miss in larger vehicles too. If I had to chance a head-on with a semi, I'd take a Micra over an F250 with a load of concrete pavers in the back any day. .

Comment: Great article.

Weinstein is redundant.  The details don't matter.  We know the dynamics of abusive personalities, that bullies are common, and that sexual harassment happens to every woman.  

But understanding our normal responses to abusive personalities is vital.  

Whether it's a real wolf or a human predator, our response is flight or fight.  Then we push the memory back and move on.  That's not minimizing, but to not fuhgettaboutit would be to live in fear, which is crippling.

So, speaking to women:  Trust your gut response.  And you don't have to come forward, but tell at least one trusted friend.

To predators:  You don't understand gossip.  Women do.  It's how we protect ourselves and it's powerful.  Don't think you're getting away with it just because you can't see the whispering crowd watching for evidence.

To us:  What's fair is to say what you know and how you know it.  Gossip has its risks, but until somebody has a better idea, ignoring it is what's unethical.

Comment: Karan: Yours was the ultimate harm reduction. For the most part, harm reduction means recognizing and accepting the imperfections of life, and doing what it takes  to lower the numbers. A good example of harm reduction is needle exchanges in order to reduce the number of HIV and Hep- C infections. It is not condoning or condemning IV use, but remaining neutral and viewing the issue as being medical rather than criminal. It allows the problem to remain above ground so it can be dealt with in a humane manner. That is just a rough explanation; there is obviously much more to it.

Harm reduction is a well known and academic study, and can be found in peer review databases. 

In my view, the harm reduction principle can be applied successfully to other contentious social and political issues. give it a try; stretch your imagination.

Comment: I don't think you understand how Social Security works. 

We spend our whole lives paying into Social Security. When we retire, or if we are disabled in life, then we withdraw. It's not a handout the young are paying to the old. It's getting back the money that you have already put in. 

YES, it's being used, not just sitting in a vault---but the amount coming in isn't the same as what is going out. Same thing with your taxes and refunds. That money is used by the government---often in investments. It's a free loan we are all giving to our government, expecting to be paid back. 

Given that, it's up to the government to figure out how to pay us back, rather than just blowing it all. Of course, governments seem to be very bad at this.

Comment: There's sufficient information in the article to negate all your criticisms.

1. The process was a civil action resulting in an award of $40,000. This is a normal procedure in the courts.

2. A law was clearly broken: an illegal video tape was made. But proving who made it in a way that could satisfy a criminal charge would be very difficult. Not to mention the fact that it was probably the husband, who's now dead. 

3. It may be eminently sensible to overturn a will that a person makes while under reduced capacity, or is being improperly influenced by people who will gain from it. In this case the sister was intimately involved in writing the will, and she became the sole beneficiary. Worse yet, the terms of the revised will did not satisfy the intent of the maker: to look after his children. It's logical that the person best able to look after the children is their mother, not the deceased's sister. Hence the mother became the final beneficiary.

Comment: Trump have said repeatedly that he wants to re-negotiate NAFTA and if that fails the U.S. will withdraw from this trade agreement. 

The Trudeau government have not received a mandate from the people to re-negotiate NAFTA. Already 25 years old a clear electoral mandate is essential. Therefore Trudeau position should be the U.S. must actually have withdrawn from NAFTA before we decide what to do. There are three options:

1. Do nothing. I.e. keep NAFTA between Canada and Mexico. Revert back to the original FTA which is still in force.
2. Get a new mandate from the people to start a new trade agreement with the U.S. under new terms. 
3. Proceed to establish Trans Pacific Partnership without the U.S., which should be renamed and revised with new negotiations. Or even roll Canada-Mexico NAFTA into the revised TPP. 

In all cases, a new trade agreement with the U.S. after it unilaterally cancelled its participation can proceed only with a new electoral mandate.

Comment: I suggest you read the transcript of the judge's ruling. He specifically commented on the small amount of DNA evidence, and explained why it did not prove sexual activity.

"I'm just pointing out that in the case of robbery, the testimony of the complainant that the money was taken without their consent is generally sufficient."

That is incorrect. A complaint that money was stolen will certainly initiate an investigation, but if there is no corroborating evidence to show that money actually was stolen, then there will be no conviction. Otherwise people could say, "I had a hundred dollars in my wallet and now it's gone. So-and-so was the only person I can remember seeing yesterday, so obviously he took it." The police search so-and-so, but can't find any money. Questioning the complainant again, they find her recollection of the time in question was virtually nil. She may even have given the money away voluntarily. 

There would be no trial for robbery, let alone a conviction.

Comment: I couldn't swim until I was thirteen. I went on a camping (when I was twelve) trip for two weeks and for half of that trip we went on a canoe trip. My parents were clear I could not swim so I always wore a life vest in the canoe and the camp counsellors were aware and helpful. I remember this trip like it was yesterday, it was in 1966. 
So, I'm sure I wasn't the only guy who could not swim. But the counsellors knew exactly who could not. I wonder what happened on this particular trip? If you know which kids can't swim , shouldn't there be precise  supervision? That kid shouldn't have drowned.

Comment: Really? Have you ever attempted to appeal your Muni Tax Appraisal?  The law says the appraisal should be the fair market value of the property. Fair market value is defined as the price a willing buyer will pay a willing seller in an arms-length sale.  I bought my home from an elderly couple who had lived there nearly 30 years. They put the home on the market at the tax appraised value. 3 years and 6 price price reductions later I purchased it for $100,000 less than the muni appraisal. When I appealed, the Appraisal Board agreed to split the difference. I could take that deal or sue the Muni in district court.  While waiting my hearing, a guy in front of me was denied even though he had appraisals from 3 appraisal companies. The Muni tax appraisal is actually based on replacement value their internal computer model generates using square footage, house style and construction, but ignores age, condition and setting; key factors in the value of a property. Been there ... twice!!

Comment: The state is in a budget crisis and this is what we're worrying about?  Look I get it, no one likes having to change their clock radio twice a year.  And its a fair statement that its not real clear what advantage DST gives us in Alaska.  All fair statements.  But the truth is that changing our time requires a massive investment in overhaul of everything computerized in the state.  Every cell phone, every laptop, every bank application, every control system whether its valves on a pipeline or street lights or air traffic control has daylight savings time programmed into it and would require a 'fix' to resolve it.  Some of those fixes would be relatively simple; some would be extremely complicated.  This issue is a solution looking for a problem to solve.  Honestly, don't we have more pressing things to worry about right now?

Comment: Yes, portable toilets and bucket systems are not ideal. But providing services to informal settlements is a hellish task. The local authorities, be they DA or ANC, can never keep up with the demand, and providing any service other than temporary simply is not possible, due to the layout of informal settlements. The people who live there should know that better than anyone else.

The real issue is a worldwide problem - economic migrations from rural or less viable urban area to viable urban areas. This issue is outside of the control of local authorities, who have to deal with the fallout of national government failure.

It's a fact. So how do we deal with it? Imo, because the users have no alternative, and because the authorities, how well intentioned or cynical they may be, can only do so much, it is in the users interest to at least keep their allocated cubicle clean. And I'm sure many do. (I've seen toilets with locks on them).

Zille has nothing to do with it ...

Comment: "...signs of cognitive and memory impairment, for example, uncharacteristic irrationality, confusion and distress...One does not need to be a medical professional to recogconize (sic) these indicators of dementia".
Indeed! One does not need to be a medical professional to make that mistaken diagnosis.
In fact, "signs of cognitive and memory impairment, for example, uncharacteristic irrationality, confusion and distress" - i.e. delirium -can be the result of a severe illness and infection in an otherwise cognitive intact person. For example Pneumonia or an UTI. Could even be seen in a normal young person in the 24 hour post-operative period.
I have met patients with dementia who have been quite lucid, rational, and calm. Just their time frame is out of whack. Example: one patient told me that she didn't want her son to marry the girl he was dating. The son said: "It's too late now - we've been married for 35 years!".
Unfortunately it's a common mistake to confuse delirium with dementia.

Comment: For food to taste good, it has to have either sugar or fat. Going low carb means going high fat for good taste. (The "To Your Health" column on page A10 of today's paper warns not to eat too much protein.) A high-fat, moderate-protein, low-carb diet is the healthiest, provided you eat only healthy fats. Most of the fats and oils in our food supply are not healthy. They cause inflammation and chronic diseases. We've been getting bad advice on fats for a long time, and still are.

All fats are healthy in their pristine state. They are bad when they are mutated, like becoming oxidized or hydrogenated. Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) are good when you get them directly from fresh whole foods, but in a bottle or in processed foods they are bad; the refining process mutates them. PUFAs can't take heat. Cooking with canola oil or soy oil or safflower oil is toxic. We don't need more research. We just need to pay attention to the good research we already have, like here:
http://drcate.com

Comment: What is really needed to stifle this artificial divisive populist Gerry Butts' tactic is to establish a set of rules that realistically and accurately calculates a person's hourly compensation in the work force.

So, what we need to know is the cost to the employer of all benefits, pensions, vacation and statutory holidays, etc.  their employees receive. 

In the private sector this has, at times, been valued at 20% of a person's salary.

I would expect this number could be even higher in the public sector - perhaps as high as 30% or more.

Finally,of course we would need to know how many hours a person works on a regular/normal work schedule.

After that it is simple arithmetic to determine an hourly wage.

Then we would really see who the wealthy ones are.

The one missing factor is how does one establish the value of the jobs created by the self-employed folks Gerry is targeting.

Comment: That was my thought as well David.  If you are truly dealing with play money or highly speculative trades the last place you want to do it is where it will cost you non-recoverable contribution room and the inability to use the losses to offset gains.

Comment: A lot of COs Ive met feel like they're anything but supported by the institution administration. At SCCC they're caught between a rock and hard place, admin on one side, inmates on the other. One example, Admin issued an order to remove do-rags and confiscate them, but still allowed them to be sold at commissary, so inmates would pay just to have it taken away immediately. COs refused to confiscate because they rightly felt it was going to cause major friction in an institution that was only half-staffed. Comment: As a general matter, I do not disagree with the assertion that the market "prices in" regulation. But it is a weak case with respect to the Clean Power Plan in particular.

As this EIA report sets forth, the shift from coal to natural gas began to occur in the mid-2000s as the price of natural gas dropped below that of coal. The drop in price was largely tied to an increase in the supply of natural gas as a result of fracking. The Clean Power Plan wasn't issued until 2014, & was, of course, stayed in 2016 by the Supreme Court (and which wasn't going to go into effect until 2022 anyway).
https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.php?id=25392

So the pattern was set before the Clean Power Plan was issued or went into effect & will continue despite the Trump EO repealing it.

2014/15: +$1.9B

Comment: This special election didn't cost the taxpayer anything.

"RCW 29A.04.410
Costs borne by constituencies.
Every city, town, and district is liable for its proportionate share of the costs when such elections are held in conjunction with other elections held under RCW 29A.04.321 and 29A.04.330.
Whenever any city, town, or district holds any primary or election, general or special, on an isolated date, all costs of such elections must be borne by the city, town, or district concerned.
The purpose of this section is to clearly establish that the county is not responsible for any costs involved in the holding of any city, town, or district election."

Comment: Two points.
First, the battle with the provinces demonstrates why the federal government should get out of providing any funding other than equalization payments.  The provinces have all the same taxing powers of the federal government except for import duties but they also collect all the money from lotteries.  Of course, to stop funding the provinces the federal government needs to drop their taxes by exactly the amount of the cut in transfers or it will be nothing but a huge tax grab.  By having the federal government inserting itself into provincial funding simply increases the bureaucracy of both to monitor and report on the spending.
Second, provinces are mature forms of government that are responsible to the voting public.  If the residents of the province doesn't like what the provincial government is doing, it can vote them out.  Hence it makes perfect sense to provide equalization payments with no strings attached.

Comment: Easy to say.  But life is rarely that black and white.  29 years ago I was travelling at night with my pregnant wife on the 401 near Trenton.  An elderly man had parked his car on the shoulder and crossed the highway on foot.  Apparently he was lost and decided he needed to read a sign facing the other direction on the highway.  I tried to avoid him, but he was moving towards my lane and I hit him at speed.  He died from head injuries at the scene.   To this day I wonder if I could have swerved more aggressively.  If I had would I have endangered my wife and future son.

Arguably I caused a pedestrian's death by driving.  Should I never drive again?  Fault is not always black and white.  The law should also be nuanced.

Comment: Normally this would be under provincial jurisdiction - local work and undertaking but under our Constitution that jurisdiction is pre-empted:

"92. In each Province the Legislature may exclusively make Laws in relation to Matters coming within the Classes of Subjects next hereinafter enumerated; that is to say,
...
10. Local Works and Undertakings other than such as are of the following Classes:
(a) Lines of Steam or other Ships, Railways, Canals, Telegraphs, and other Works and Undertakings connecting the Province with any other or others of the Provinces, or extending beyond the Limits of the Province:"

As policy (not law) the feds try to bring the provinces onside but if necessary they can go unilaterally.

The most effective opposition will come from First Nations because any pipeline crossing their lands invokes a duty upon the Crown to consult and accommodate.  And that duty has become more onerous under recent SCOC decisions - currently nearing a veto based on the latest cases.

Comment: Are you an economist? I am not, but neither am I "unschooled."

I understand the authors are credible people and I respect that. We would have to read (and understand) those 50 studies, assess their quality and relevance, and draw our own conclusions. I know enough about research to know that you can cite 50 or 500 studies in some domains to find the results you like. Many "facts" are actually interpretations, subject to assumptions and contextual factors. Some studies present models that do not replace the real world which is very much messier. 

My goal was to bring forward some countervailing evidence of an ongoing, real-world situation that is also being studied by some smart people. I don't know why they chose not to include the Seattle results. They too will have biases. But their finding probably shouldn't be dismissed quite so quickly by you or others.

Comment: The replacement cost of a battery for Nissan Leaf is listed at US$5499.00. Comment: So let's look at Yakabuski's claims...

Subsidies of $8,000+ won't drive early sales/leases of electric vehicles (EVs), but exemptions from hypothetical road tolls or congestion charges would?

The government is afraid of implementing the $50/tonne CO2 tax (11.5¢/liter gasoline) that it has already announced, but a $100/tonne CO2 tax (23¢/liter) would meet Canada's GHG emissions targets?

The price of lithium and copper will go up because of the growing use of EVs? There's less than 7 kg of (recyclable) lithium in a current high-capacity 85 kWh battery, such as in the Tesla S, and *current* known lithium resources are sufficient to make one such battery for every person on Earth. An electric vehicle uses 50 to 60 kg more copper (also recyclable) in an EV than an ICE one. Annual global production of copper is 18 million tonnes, enough for 250 million EVs.

Yakabuski too often twists facts to fit his desired outcome, and this column is no exception.

Comment: We shouldn't have a corporate tax at all.  It's double-taxation, because we also tax dividends and capital gains.

Corporations don't pay taxes.  Their customers do.  It's a cost of doing business that's added onto price in order to net an after-tax profit that's sufficient to attract investment capital, relative to risk.  When you over-tax and over-regulate corporations, YOU pay for it in the price of everything you buy.

Example of how that 21.2% was derived.  XYZ Inc makes $10 million of profit this year, on which it's tax would normally be $3.5 million.  But it lost #3,943,000 last year, which is carried forward as a tax deduction from this year's earnings, making the net taxable income $6,057,000, and the net tax $2.22 million on this year's profits, but 35% of the net profits earned over both years.

Comment: TDW,

The government should not, in my opinion, be subsidizing the purchases of cars like the Tesla Model S or the BMW i8. These are luxury cars and anyone who would purchase them does not need a subsidy. In California purchase incentives/subsidies of up to $7,500 are offered to EV buyers but the amount of the subsidy decreases quickly as household income goes up. California is trying to help lower income families replace old and highly polluting cars. Interestingly, in California, only 70% of EV buyers ever apply for the state government subsidy. California is going to experiment with point of sale rebates to see if the 70% number can be increased while, at the same time, further accelerating EV sales.

https://evobsession.com/california-may-shift-ev-subsidies-point-sale-rebates/

http://www.autoblog.com/2017/05/15/california-point-of-sale-plug-in-rebates/

Comment: >But, how do you measure and make the distinction between man made and natural phenomena?
I bet you think you're being rational and not just quoting another completely idiotic piece of denialist propaganda.
It's actually ridiculously easy to measure the impact of man-made activity - we've been doing it for decades. You see all carbon are not created equal. The carbon from fossil fuels have a particular mixture of isotopes you don't find in any other source (and nothing except humans burn fossil fuels). The increased CO2 in the atmosphere - consists entirely of carbon that could ONLY have come from fossil fuels - volcanic CO2 for example has a a completely different isotopic distribution.
We CAN tell where it came from. We can tell how much came from where.
Volcanoes are the only other significant source of CO2. The USGS (world's greatest volcano experts) published a paper with the numbers. Total volcanic CO2 per annum 0.025% of what coal plants ALONE add.

Comment: The test of love is sacrifice. How much is one prepared to sacrifice, give up for the sake of the beloved.
Jesus Christ, God made man through his Passion and Death on the Cross offered Himself up for the sins of the world; my sins and your sins, His creation was loved by God and the Father accepted this sacrifice and Christ rose again to sit at His right hand.
Here is an explanation of self sacrifice.
A lover finds his love not reciprocated because the object of his desire loves another.
The true lover would only be concerned with his beloved's happiness not his own.
He would, therefore, do everything in his power to encourage his beloved in the pursuit of her happiness.
He would subjugate his own feelings and desires, however, painful that may be for him to will the happiness of his beloved in the arms of another and therein is situated the sacrifice.
A scenario in an ideal world, you may say, but an explanation of the true meaning of sacrifice.

Comment: I find these articles theoretical at best. Most retirees in my generation have built their portfolios around DC plans (RRSP's and RPP's). The government determines the minimum amount one can withdraw from such plans (as soon as they are converted to RRIF's and LIF's). This number is 4% at age 65 and increases yearly after that age. Discussions regarding how much money you can "safely" withdraw are thus moot point for the majority of us. The bigger question revolves around when you should convert and how you manage your funds in the interim (assuming you are retired). Anyone spending only their dividend interest is a) most likely drawing a DB pension and b) does not have their funds in tax sheltered investments that will require conversion by age 71.

Comment: Actually, there's no evidence for your assumption that the complaints are "faulty" (whatever that means), especially when most sex assault victims don't make police complaints but many of them do report the crimes to sexual assault support groups instead.  

What has been proven is that the rate of unfounded cases vary substantially between different police departments due to the failure of some departments to investigate or even document complaints; and, we've also seen many cases now of judges being taken to task for not properly understanding sexual assault law resulting in retrial.

These new statistics point to more problems that can be addressed, one being that complainants should report the crime to police right away so they can gather all the evidence.  But of course that's not going to happen in jurisdictions where police are reluctant to even investigate complaints.

Comment: There's one missing piece in this very interesting article. The basic English translation here is incorrect. The French word for globalisation is "mondialisation" and when you put "sauvage" before it, it does not mean "savage globalization," it means "uncontrolled." The centrists will use it to mean that, while the extreme-right in France use the technical term to also include the notion of "savages." So they get both protectionism and racism in one word. Western media should not repeat this-- the phrase in English is uncontrolled globalization.

Comment: We are obliged to keep forgiving. The individual seeking forgiveness must ask for it, be it from God or fellow human.

Judaism teaches those who have done wrong  seek forgiveness. The offender must sincerely ask pardon and seek to correct the wrongs he has done. After a certain point-- three sincere apologies, an attempt at restitution, a clear indication that the person has changed - it becomes the obligation of the wronged party to forgive. 

The rabbis agree that teshuvah (repentance) requires five elements: recognition of one's sins as sins (hakarát ha-chét'), remorse (charatá), desisting from sin (azivát ha-chét'), restitution where possible (peira'ón), and confession (vidúi). The tradition is also quite clear, however, that  if they are done without desisting from sin, they do not constitute teshuva.

What Jesus changed was the number of time we should forgive. The rest reads like a manual for the sacrament of Penance.

Comment: Conventional oil peaked around 2005.  The increased production has come from more expensive and high carbon emissions unconventional oil (oil sands, fracking, deep water, Venezuela heavy oil etc.)   These cost more and have progressively lower EROIs.  

The reason for the current low price of oil is not real cost but increased production from fracked sources (mostly) which have yet to turn one positive dollar.

The reserves available to humanity are in the neighbourhood of 1.5 trillion bbls and we are using around 90 million a day.  90 x 365 = 33 billion bbl/year.  So around a 50 year lifespan of reserves with real costs getting progressively higher as more marginal reserves (higher hanging fruit) are exploited.

Economic theory is very hard to apply when printing presses are running overtime.  Best to change energy horses long before one runs out of steam and the other has yet to be born.

Cheers,
John Meyer

Comment: Zero-based budgeting would go a long way to eliminating the lies built into the current 'budgeting' process.

"Zero-based budgeting is a method of budgeting in which all expenses must be justified for each new period. Zero-based budgeting starts from a "zero base" and every function within an organization is analyzed for its needs and costs. Budgets are then built around what is needed for the upcoming period regardless of whether the budget is higher or lower than the previous one."

Two standard Questions have to be answered:

Are the current activities efficient and effective?
Should current activities be eliminated or reduced to fund higher-priority new programs? Or to reduce the current budget?

Comment: It wasn't a defense.  Hardly.  

Imagine that the white supremacists had their protest in one park, while those opposed had their protest in another park a few blocks over, standing up against hatred.  Today, we'd be talking about how the white supremacists looked like complete idiots and how reasonably the protesters responded.

Instead, some of the protesters went looking for a fight, the situation escalated, a nutbar lost his cool, and today we're talking about deaths while the extreme right postures about the loss of free speech.

A pedestrian has the right to cross the road when their light turns green.  But it is poor judgement to cross without looking anyway, or to assume a vehicle approaching at speed will stop.  It is unwise to place oneself in such danger just because one has the right.  

Unfortunate decisions were made by all sides...including the officials who granted the permit in the first place and then failed to have enough police to keep the two sides far apart.

Comment: My Dad came as a Home Child from Scotland, worked on farms for 15 years and then served as a sergeant in the RCA throughout WWII, D-Day and the Liberation included.   We have been here since arriving on a War Bride ship in 1946. Yes, we were born in Britain but my parents; documents say we would be given citizenship on arrival in Canada,  and the RCA soldiers served as Canadians,  not British.,no matter where they had been born.   The 28 year rule for reaffirmation was not in existence before 1946.    My brother served a career in the Canadian Navy, who certainly regarded him as a citizen, and later worked with a police force,  yet today we have had no Canadian citizenship since 2004.

Comment: Wait a minute... there are legal vacation rentals and there are illegal vacation rentals. No one is proposing to shut-down the legal vacation rentals, but the Expedia "paid" report lumps in both legal and illegal rentals to make their numbers look bigger. Why does the Star Advertiser fall for these self-interest industry reports that are really just propaganda pieces?

Illegal vacation rentals in "residential-zoning" are illegal for a reason. These businesses take housing away from residents and they change the residential character of our neighborhoods. Neighbors want neighbors living in their neighborhood, not a revolving door of strangers every week. Short-term tenants have little interest in public agencies or in the welfare of the citizenry.  They do not participate in local government, coach paddling, or join the hospital guild.  Literally they are here today and gone tomorrow--without engaging in the sort of activities that weld and strengthen a community.

Comment: Three years later, there was the Battle of Blair Mountain which followed the Matewan Massacre.

"The Battle of Blair Mountain was the largest labor uprising in United States history and one of the largest, best-organized, and most well-armed uprisings since the American Civil War. For five days in late August and early September 1921, in Logan County, West Virginia, some 10,000 armed coal miners confronted 3,000 lawmen and strikebreakers, called the Logan Defenders, who were backed by coal mine operators during an attempt by the miners to unionize the southwestern West Virginia coalfields. The battle ended after approximately one million rounds were fired, and the United States Army intervened by presidential order."
 
My relatives were in the center of that one.  And there are still unlocated private firearms in their possession---and always will be.   When the US Army brings in Army bombers and troops to support the coal industry, the extended family does not forget it, ever.

Comment: I have no dog in this fight but as is so often the case things are not as simple as they seem.

Unintended Consequences... Despite the emotion surrounding this particular deal, the consequences of breaking this lease using the "subject to appropriation"  language is likely to have unintended negative consequences beyond the values of this lease or any claimed damage.  The "subject to appropriation" language is a standard and required clause in all State contracts.  The purpose is to protect the State if revenue is not available to pay under terms of the contract.  It is not intended to give the State the prerogative to change their mind. The unintended consequence of using this clause to break this lease will be to make all future contracts, leases and bond sales more expensive or in some cases impossible.  Especially those contracts involving financing.
