Comment: Trio of judges highly ethical, June 24, 2016 in Star-Advertiser Letters to Editor

I am writing not as vice chairman of the Honolulu Ethics Commission, but solely as a citizen.
A Star-Advertiser editorial repeated an insinuation that Mayor Kirk Caldwell appointed three retired state judges to interfere with the operations of the commission (“Don’t let city ethics work languish,” Star-Advertiser, Our View, June 17).

That insinuation is false. I personally have known the three judges for more than 30 years and know for a fact they would not be a party to any such thing. In my opinion, they each have the highest personal character for honesty, integrity and moral courage of anyone I know.
I have observed that their decisions as commissioners are always based on the merits and what they honestly believe is fair, just and right.

Michael A. Lilly
Pacific Heights

Comment: We are currently in an interglacial period, i.e. a warmer period between glaciations.  The glaciations occur and will likely continue because of the current positions of Antarctica over the south pole and the nearly landlocked north pole which limits circulation of ocean waters to the north pole. Without this positioning of Antarctica and the Asian and North American  continents, there have been periods of earth history where the climate was extremely warm to the point that much of North America was underwater.  

We have had periods of extremely cold weather as recently as the late 1700s, i.e. Valley Forge where a large number of Continental Army soldiers froze to death.   If glaciation were to return, we would again have a thousand feet of ice over New York City and other northern parts of the U.S.  Considering the alternative, some global warming to prevent the return of the glaciers may not be a bad thing.

Comment: If the older son went home on an earlier flight because there was extra room on that flight, then the ticket he used was the paid ticket. Now, I do not condone how the Delta person spoke to the parents, but I think the parents were just trying to get a freebie.  We had that happen once where my daughter flew home on an earlier flight, but our plane was not full either.  Her seat was between my wife and me, but no one took it, so when the plane took off, we just used it as "storage" for my wife's jacket and purse once we were in flight.  But, we knew that if someone came along to sit there, we did not have a say.

Comment: Alexandra,
I have long tried to be an "independent," although I will readily admit that in terms of politics, I lean right, while in terms of social justice, I lean a bit to the left.  Those ARE my biases, and I don't think I've ever tried to hide them.  My wife and I have tended to be TV news junkies for a while now, and I HAVE seen a lot of what I will call "screaming."

I don't profess to be a constitutional scholar, but while I law school I DID tend to load up on constitutional law classes.  So I DO find it more than a little amusing to listen to the punditry and commentators talk about the constitution and what it does/does not say.

As to "screaming," all you need to is to tune into the evening news to see it, daily.  My point is that we need to get past that, and back to respectful disagreement in society.    

As to the nuclear option, much ado about nothing.  The "60-vote" threshold is a senate rule, relatively recent at that.  It required civility in Congress to work.

Comment: The issue isn't whether a body part such as sperm or ovum or zygote is biologically human or alive. Each cell has a full complement of DNA. In the context of abortion, totipotency goes to the question of potential, not certainty of the end goal, which under perfect conditions produces a fully formed, viable person. The core issues are at what point does that occur in both a biological and legal sense, and who is legally in charge of the situation in the interim? I come down squarely on the woman's side. The woman is a legal person with all that implies. She has a right to privacy and bodily integrity. Is a zygote a person in the legal sense? No. Nor is a fetus or an embryo. In Roe v Wade, the Court decided that the state has an "important and legitimate interest in protecting the potentiality of human life" from the point of viability on, but that prior to viability, the woman's fundamental rights are more compelling than that of the state. I adhere to that position.

Comment: In August, 1940, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge stood on the floor of the United States Senate and quoted the following from the Episcopalian Bishop of Massachusetts: "If our civilization is to be a Christian civilization, then Christ must be behind and beneath it. The man or woman, however humble, who is by life and teaching, trying to lift just one person up to a finer character, is at the very heart of the movement for international peace." There was anger in the Congress at the time because President Roosevelt was seeking an unprecedented third term, Congress the day before had established the SEC, Americans' standard of living had declined precipitously from 1930 levels, and a year later America would enter WWII. The Bishop finished his remarks by quoting the Apostle John: "Little children, love one another." I'm not sure what any of it means, but I think Pope Francis is talking about it.

Comment: The issue before the Supreme Court is not whether individual students will be accepted by the LSUC - it's whether TWU's possible future law school will be accredited, given the rules it says it will require of all students.

In fact, there is a procedure for non-accredited law schools to request that their students be assessed by the LSUC on an individual basis.  We don't know what the LSUC's answer would be because TWU has never asked.

The LSUC had a statutory duty to make sure that accredited law schools do not discriminate in their admissions policies.  This was the right decision, and the only decision they could have come to given their statutory mandate.

Comment: In my opinion, as a trained military historian and Canadian Army veteran, the Dieppe raid must be put into the historical context of 1942.  You must actually walk the ground at Puys, Dieppe and Pourville to appreciate the difficulties in mounting the raid.  Originally, as OP RUTTER, it was to be supported by massive British naval gunfire support, aerial bombing and paratroops.  OP RUTTER was cancelled as it was not supported by Gen. Montgomery or Adm. Pound. RAF Air Marshal Leigh-Mallory noted that the large stones on the beach would impede the movement of the tanks.  The Canadian Army in the Second World War was not a colonial force subordinate to British Command - the decision to participate was very much a Canadian decision. Much of the blame for the OP JUBILEE raid was the responsibility of the Canadian government and the senior Canadian military leadership - the Army had been in the UK since 1939 and wanted to see some action. Lessons learned at Dieppe were indeed useful for D-Day

Comment: This round will inevitably fail, because de Mistura, obviously, misreads the situation. Whatever proposals his team is "finishing" won't work, because they don't reflect the situation on the ground where the government side has an upper hand. The UN wants to focus on idealistic goals and that's wishful thinking. "New constitution" and "free and fair elections"? Come on, the country has been in a state of civil war for six years. And they hope that elections will solve its problems? No, elections alone won't lead to democracy, and that should not be the goal in the first place. Successful democratic transitions in the past almost always relied on existing (and strong) state institutions. The only secular institution that is strong enough in Syria right now to maintain any semblance of order is the SAA. But this plan obviously hopes to destroy the Syrian state through "free and fair elections". So, it's more of a soft regime change. Again, it's wishful thinking and it's going to fail.

Comment: All good questions; information is everywhere around us, on the ground, on our skin, soil trees and air. And the same can be said about what we see thru a telescope. But just because we're taught what dirt is for, what air and trees are for; don't mean we know everything about it. Are we aware of all micro processes going on around us? I thank science for providing a method to comprehend some of these unseen processes, and further reveals in most cases is that we are just scratching the surface to yet more info.
Point is there's so much more to educate ourselves about what going on here taking into account microcosmically and macrocosmically, that we must include a broader awareness of the here and now. History, Art, and Culture are just as viable a study to also help comprehend the unseen opportunities that could be staring us right in the face. What few culturally significant places we still have left needs adequate protection so future cultural practitioners are able to investigate.

Comment: 4.6 Billion years is the estimated age of the planet.  The reason you should care what happened millions (and even billions) of years ago is that it could offer a reasonable explanation to what is happening now.  There have been multiple extreme changes in climate of planet earth.  There have been multiple ice ages and periods of extreme heat.  Wouldn't you agree that if the climate of the planet has always been changing for 4.6 billion years that it probably still is?  That's just common sense.  Tying to look at a 100 year sample size for a planet that has been here for 4.6 billion years isn't even a relevant sample size.  The natural cycles are here now and will always be here just like they always have been.  Thinking you could actually do anything about it is naive, conceited, and humorous.

Comment: "There are far more dual income families today than in the 1970's."
============

Actually somewhat surprisingly there AREN'T many more dual-income households than there were in the 1970's.

The reason is quite simple: there are a lot more single people living on their own and single-parent families than there used to be.  If you were to ONLY look at the two-parent families then yes, a much larger proportion of them are dual income families.  However two-parent families make up a much smaller proportion of all households than they did in the 1970's, so when looking at all households the number of dual-income households hasn't changed much.

Comment: “Any sign should be low key. Something you don’t even see.”

In regards to individual donors, it's a nice unobtrusive acknowledgement of their contributions, something for the passerby to stumble upon.

In regards to organizations and businesses, branding is most effective when it's embedded into the everyday seemlessly. If we "discover" that a park is sponsored by X group, we implicitly garner more positive feelings towards X group.

I'm more wary of things that are low-key, because subtlety is the most powerful tool there is in rooting and manipulating behaviors and emotions in people.

Comment: Years ago I volunteered at the local Legal Aid as an intake person. 
I talked to thousands of low income Lane county residents who had civil problems. It was terribly underfunded but did a great deal with very little. On the criminal side, if one is accused of robbing a bank, one is given a lawyer if poor. However, on the civil law side of things, if one is poor and needs to file for divorce or is being brought into court by an ex who has a lot of money and wants custody, one may end up bewildered and lose custody, without legal help. 
Many Lane county residents receive legal notices every day, but without legal help cannot file paperwork to reply. 
If I have one criticism of the legal aid system, it is that they tend to operate quietly, so the community often doesn't know the great work they do. Their funding should be doubled, not cut. 
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Comment: As a newly appointed member of the fishery council, I'm setting the record straight. All of this has been published long ago. A lot has been done to protect that area and to ensure that fishing can continue indefinitely.

As for AP's story about the problems with the longline fleet, it's a terrible tragedy if people are being abused. Any mistreatment is unacceptable and should be stopped. It should also be noted that the article said some crewmen sign up again and again, for more than a decade. Which means that not all skippers or boat owners are treating people poorly. 

You make this sound like a game, Bryant. It's not.

Fish has always been an important food source for the people who live on these islands. Longline fishermen provide up to 50 sustainable tons a day, and that contributes a great deal to Hawaii's ability to be more self-sufficient.
